facts.text: Unregistered document executed by petitioner's husband on April 26, 1948 called itself a lease giving right to cut bamboos, fuel wood and teak.

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1948, he executed an unregistered document, that called itself a lease, in favour of his wife, the petitioner. The deed gives her the right to enter upon certain areas i

facts.text: Term of deed from April 26, 1948 to December 26, 1960 for Rs. 26,000.

facts.text: Petitioner worked the forests till 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The term of the deed is from April 26, 1948 to December 26, 1960, and the companysideration is Rs. 26,000. The petitioner says that she worked the forests till 1950.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 enacted and came into force on January 26, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In that year the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950, which came into force on January 26, 1951, was enacted.

facts.text: Under s.3 of the Act, proprietary rights vested in State on March 31, 1951 for this area.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 of that Act, all proprietary rights in the land vest in the State on and from the date fixed in a numberification issued under sub-s.  1 . The date fixed for the vesti

facts.text: After March 31, 1951, petitioner stopped from cutting trees.

anchor.surface_text: The date fixed for the vesting in this area was March 31, 1951. After that, the petitioner was stopped from cutting any more trees.

facts.text: Petitioner applied to Deputy Commissioner, Bhandara under s.6 of the Act; held on August 16, 1955 that section not applicable as transfer pre-March 16, 1950 but allowed working forests.

facts.text: Petition filed in Supreme Court under Art. 32 on August 26, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Then, as numberhing tangible happened, she made a petition to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution on August 26, 1957.

facts.text: Nature of document dated April 26, 1948 canvassed as contract, transfer, licence coupled with grant, relating to movable or immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: The foundation of the petitioners rights is the deed of April 26, 1948. The exact nature of this document was much canvassed before us in the arguments by both sides.

issues.text: Whether the petition under Article 32 is maintainable due to infringement of a fundamental right

anchor.surface_text: Since the application is under Art. 32 of the Constitution, the petitioner must make out that there has been an infringement of some fundamental right claimed by her.

issues.text: Whether the offending order infringed fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners grievance is that the offending order has infringed her fundamental right under Art. 19 1  f  and 19 1  g . She claims to have derived the fundamental rights, which are alleged to have been infringed, from a document dated April 26, 1948,

issues.text: What is the nature of the rights conferred by the document dated April 26, 1948

anchor.surface_text: The document, however, has not been registered under the Indian Registration Act. The nature of the rights claimed by the petitioner has to be ascertained on a proper interpretation of the aforesaid document.

issues.text: Whether the unregistered document affects immovable property or conveys any interest therein

anchor.surface_text: If the document is construed as conveying to her any part or share in the proprietary right of the grantor, then, not being registered under the Indian Registration Act, the document does not affect the immoveable property or give her any right to any share or interest in the immoveable property.

issues.text: Whether proprietary rights under the document vested in the State under s. 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: vested in the State under s. 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950,

anchor.surface_text: profits-a-prendre which, being an interest in land, is immoveable property

issues.text: Whether the document is a purely personal contractual right protected as fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(f) or 31(1)

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, the document is construed as a matter of contract, then assuming but without deciding that a contract is a property within Arts. 19 1  f  or 31 1  of the Constitution,

anchor.surface_text: standing timber must be a tree that is in a state fit for these purposes and, further, a tree that is meant to be converted into timber so shortly that it can already be looked upon as timber for all practical purposes even though it is still standing.

arguments.court_reasoning: State not party to contract, no acquisition or interference with contractual right beyond ordinary breach remedies

arguments.claim: Document confers contractual rights entitling to writ under Art. 32 relying on Chhotabhai precedent
arguments.court_reasoning: Chhotabhai distinguished as obiter on contract; follow later Ananda Behera (5 judges) holding no fundamental right

arguments.claim: Document is a contract conferring contractual rights, transfer, licence coupled with grant relating to movable property
arguments.court_reasoning: Not proprietary lease but licence coupled with grant; includes trees (immovable) requiring registration

arguments.claim: Document relates to immovable property
arguments.court_reasoning: Trees (non-standing timber) immovable; total grant requires registration

arguments.claim: If document conveys proprietary share, it is ineffective as unregistered under Registration Act

anchor.surface_text: If the document is construed as conveying to her any part or share in the proprietary right of the grantor, then, not being registered under the Indian Registration Act, the document does not affect the immoveable property or give her any right to any share

arguments.claim: Pure license extinguished upon vesting of proprietary rights in State under s.3 MP Act

anchor.surface_text: If the document is construed as purely a license granted to her to enter upon the land, then that license must be taken to have become extinguished as soon as the grantors proprietary rights in the land vested in the State under s. 3 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Profits-a-prendre under document ineffective as unregistered; cites Ananda Behera precedent

anchor.surface_text: if the document is construed as a license coupled with a grant, then the right acquired by her would be either in the nature of some profits-a-prendre which, being an interest in land, is immoveable property... as has been held in Ananda Behera The State of Ori

arguments.claim: Mere personal contractual right not infringed by State as not party and no acquisition

anchor.surface_text: If it is a purely personal right, then such right will have no higher efficacy than a right acquired under a contract. If, therefore, the document is construed as a matter of contract... The State is not a party to the contract and claims no benefit under it.

arguments.claim: Document not conveying proprietary interest; clause 7 only clarifies management role
Document confers only right to enter land and cut certain trees/wood (license coupled with grant), not lease of land
Right is profit a prendre equivalent, not lease per TPA s.105; cites English law
No fundamental right established; follow Ananda Behera over Chhotabhai
Contractual right to future goods not fundamental right; State not party
Right to cut timber is benefit arising out of land (immovable per General Clauses Act s.3(26))

anchor.surface_text: Following the decision in Ananda Beheras case 1 , I would hold that a right to enter on land for the purpose of cutting and carrying away timber standing on it is a benefit that arises out of land.

arguments.claim: Standing timber not immovable (TPA s.3, Reg Act s.2(6)); trees are immovable
Definition of standing timber: tree fit for timber purposes intended to be cut soon, negligible nourishment
Document covers trees not standing timber (12-year term, multiple cuttings, girth restrictions); requires registration
Section 6 MP Act not applicable to pre-March 16, 1950 transfers; lease genuine and valid

anchor.surface_text: She therefore applied to the Deputy Commissioner, Bhandara, under s. 6 2  of the Act for validating the lease. The Deputy Commissioner held, on August 16, 1955, that the section did not apply because it only applied to transfers made after March 16,

holdings.text: Whatever construction be put on the document dated April 26, 1948, the petitioner cannot complain of the breach of any of her fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider it necessary to examine or analyse the document minutely or to finally determine what we may regard as the true meaning and effect thereof, for, as will be presently seen, whatever construction be put on this document, the petitioner cannot complain of the breach of any of her fundamental rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court considers all possible interpretations of the document and concludes no fundamental right infringement under any view.

holdings.text: If construed as conveying proprietary right, unregistered document does not affect immovable property or confer interest therein.

anchor.surface_text: If the document is construed as conveying to her any part or share in the proprietary right of the grantor, then, not being registered under the Indian Registration Act, the document does not affect the immoveable property or give her any right to any share or interest in the immoveable property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Indian Registration Act requirement for documents affecting immovable property.

holdings.text: Any proprietary interest acquired vested in the State under s.3 of Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that she had acquired a share or interest in the proprietary right in spite of the document not having been registered, even then that right has vested in the State under s. 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proprietary rights vest in State on notified date per statute.

holdings.text: Pure license to enter land extinguished upon vesting of proprietary rights in State under s.3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: If the document is construed as purely a license granted to her to enter upon the land, then that license must be taken to have become extinguished as soon as the grantors proprietary rights in the land vested in the State under s. 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Licenses dependent on grantor's rights terminate when rights vest in State.

holdings.text: Profits-a-prendre, being interest in immovable property, requires registration; unregistered document ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: if the document is construed as a license coupled with a grant, then the right acquired by her would be either in the nature of some profits-a-prendre which, being an interest in land, is immoveable property... as has been held in Ananda Behera v. The State of Orissa.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in Ananda Behera; applies Registration Act to interests in land.

holdings.text: Purely personal contractual right not infringed by State, which is not a party and has not acquired it.

anchor.surface_text: If it is a purely personal right, then such right will have no higher efficacy than a right acquired under a contract... The State is not a party to the contract and claims no benefit under it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State's actions do not constitute acquisition or interference with private contract rights beyond ordinary remedies.

holdings.text: No infringement of fundamental right; petition under Art.32 not maintainable; dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: whatever rights, if any, may have accrued to the petitioner under that document on any of the several interpretations mentioned above, she cannot complain of the infringement by the State of any fundamental right for the enforcement of which alone a petition under Art. 32 is maintainable. We, therefore, agree that this petition should be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above analyses shows no fundamental right violated.

holdings.text: Document confers no proprietary rights or interest; clause 7 merely clarifies management role.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of clause 7 shows no conveyance of proprietary interest.

holdings.text: Document is licence coupled with grant to enter and remove produce (profit a prendre), not lease of immovable property.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes lease from profit a prendre based on English law and TPA s.105; cites precedents.

holdings.text: No fundamental right in licence coupled with grant or profit a prendre; follows Ananda Behera over Chhotabhai.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent hierarchy favors larger bench in Ananda Behera.

holdings.text: Standing timber is a tree fit for building etc., intended to be converted to timber soon such that it draws negligible nourishment; otherwise trees are immovable property.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and empirical distinction based on nourishment from soil, forestry practice, TPA s.3, Registration Act s.2(6), General Clauses s.3(26).

holdings.text: Document covers trees (immovable property requiring registration), not merely standing timber, due to 12-year term, girth limits, multiple cuttings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies standing timber definition to document terms showing coverage of growing trees benefiting from soil.
